2006|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/3/6/14836170/nintendo-switch-broke-sales-records-americas-zelda-two-day|title=The Switch broke Nintendo’s sales records (in the Americas, at least)|work=The Verge|access-date=2018-09-03}} Japan initially received 400,000 Wii consoles,{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/6200120.stm|title=Japanese Wii Sales Figures|date=December 2, 2006|accessdate=June 25, 2007|publisher=Kotaku}} and sold an estimated 372,000 units in two days, with Wii Sports and Wii Play being the best-selling games.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/article.php?article_id=70728|title=Early Wii figures from Japan|publisher=Eurogamer|accessdate=December 6, 2006}} Nintendo announced on December 13, 2006 that the Wii had sold 325,000 units across Europe in its first two days of availability and had sold 33,000 units in Australia in its first six days of availability, making it the fastest selling console across the entire European continent and the largest launch of a video game system in Australia.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061214203240/http://www.gamesindustry.biz/content_page.php?aid=21691|title=European consumers snap up 325,000 Wii consoles in two days // GamesIndustry.biz|date=2006-12-14|access-date=2018-09-03}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2006/12/13/nintendo-australia-breaks-30k-sales-record|title=Nintendo Australia Breaks 30k Sales Record|last=Kolan|first=Patrick|date=2006-12-13|website=IGN|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-03}} By the end of 2006, the Wii had sold 3.19 million units worldwide.{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/ir/pdf/2007/070125e.pdf#page=6|title=Consolidated Financial Highlights|date=2007-01-25|publisher=Nintendo|page=8|format=PDF|accessdate=2009-10-29}} According to the [[NPD Group]], the Wii sold more units in the United States than the [[Xbox 360]] and [[PlayStation 3]] combined in the first half of 2007.{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/gaming/news/2007/07/first-half-of-console-sales-for-2007-nintendo-the-big-winner-ps3-dead-last.ars|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070915005040/http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20070724-first-half-of-console-sales-for-2007-nintendo-the-big-winner-ps3-dead-last.html |archivedate=September 15, 2007|date= July 24, 2007|first=Ben|last=Kuchera|title= Nintendo the big winner, PS3 dead last for the first half of 2007|publisher=Ars Technica| accessdate= July 31, 2007}} This lead was even larger in the Japanese market, where it led in total sales (having outsold both consoles by factors of 2:1{{cite web |url=http://www.next-gen.biz/news/xbox-360-trumps-ps3-japan |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815200311/http://www.next-gen.biz/news/xbox-360-trumps-ps3-japan |archivedate=August 15, 2011|title=Xbox 360 Trumps PS3 in Japan|publisher=''Edge'' online|date=November 9, 2007|accessdate= November 27, 2007}} to 6:1{{cite web|url=http://wii.qj.net/Media-Create-sales-stats-July-9-15-Nintendo-continues-domination/pg/49/aid/98118|date=July 21, 2007|author= Nicolo S.|title=Media Create sales stats (July 9–15): Nintendo continues domination|publisher=qj.net|accessdate= August 1, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090211065100/http://wii.qj.net/Media-Create-sales-stats-July-9-15-Nintendo-continues-domination/pg/49/aid/98118|archivedate=February 11, 2009}} nearly every week from its launch to November 2007).{{cite web|url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=176131|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080609023356/http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=176131|archivedate=June 9, 2008| title=PS3 tops Wii in Japan... AGAIN|publisher=[[ComputerAndVideoGames.com]]|first=Mike|last=Jackson|date=November 22, 2007|accessdate= September 25, 2008}} In Australia the Wii broke the record set by the [[Xbox 360]] and became the fastest-selling game console in Australian history, selling 32,901 units within the first four days of the console's release.{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/games/wii-breaks-xbox-sales-record/2006/12/14/1165685799546.html|date=December 14, 2006|first=Asher|last=Moses|publisher=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|title=Wii breaks Xbox 360 sales record|accessdate=August 30, 2007}} It also broke the 360's Australian record for the quickest amount of time to sell 100,000 units, reaching the milestone within six months and two weeks.{{cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/100000-wiis-sold-in-australia/1100-6172865/ |first=Randolph |last=Ramsay |title=100,000 Wiis sold in Australia |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |date= June 21, 2007 |accessdate=October 31, 2017}} The Wii became the fastest selling console in the United Kingdom at the time, selling 1 million units in just 38 weeks after launch.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016161021/http://nintendoplayers.com:80/article.php?articleID=1006|title=Nintendo Players - Wii Sets UK Sales Record|date=2007-10-16|access-date=2018-09-01}} On September 12, 2007, the ''[[Financial Times]]'' reported that the Wii had surpassed the Xbox 360 (released a year earlier) and had become market leader in home-console sales for the seventh generation, based on sales figures from [[Enterbrain]], NPD Group and [[GfK]]. This was the first time a Nintendo console led its generation in sales since the [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System]].{{cite web|title=Nintendo Wii Outsells All Other Game Consoles|publisher=Ziff Davis|work=PC World|date=September 12, 2007|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2182666,00.asp|accessdate=September 21, 2012}} On July 11, 2007, Nintendo warned that the Wii would remain in short supply throughout that calendar year.{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2007/07/11/news/companies/wii/index.htm|publisher=CNN|date=July 11, 2007|title=Christmas morn without a Wii? |accessdate=October 23, 2008}} In December, [[Reggie Fils-Aimé]] revealed that Nintendo was producing approximately 1.8 million Wii consoles each month.{{cite web|url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/Technology/GadgetGuide/story?id=4001054&page=1 |date=December 18, 2007|title=Can't Find a Wii? Take a Rain Check|first=Ashley|last=Phililps|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=October 23, 2008}} Some UK stores still had a shortage of consoles in March 2007,{{cite web|url=http://wii.ign.com/articles/770/770565p1.html|title=UK Wiis "Like Gold Dust"|date=March 6, 2007|accessdate=April 18, 2007|publisher=IGN|first=Rob|last=Burman|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070316140618/http://wii.ign.com/articles/770/770565p1.html#|archive-date=March 16, 2007|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} demand still outpaced supply in the United States in June 2007,{{cite web|url=http://www.komonews.com/news/tech/8252247.html |title=Demand for Wii still outpaces supply |date=June 29, 2007 |accessdate=July 1, 2007 |publisher=komo-tv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120507114232/http://www.komonews.com/news/tech/8252247.html |archivedate=May 7, 2012 }} and the console was "selling out almost as quickly as it hits retail shelves" in Canada in April 2008. In October 2008 Nintendo announced that between October and December the Wii would have its North American supplies increased considerably from 2007 levels,{{cite press release|url=http://www.nintendo.ca/cgi-bin/usersite/display_info.cgi?lang=en&pageNum=9&id=1955846 |title=Nintendo's holiday 2008: Wii Speak Channel, Club Nintendo, more surprises |publisher=Nintendo |date=October 2, 2008 |accessdate=October 23, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081112130457/http://www.nintendo.ca/cgi-bin/usersite/display_info.cgi?lang=en |archivedate=November 12, 2008 }} while producing 2.4 million Wii units a month worldwide (compared to 1.6 million per month in 2007).{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/oct/27/business/fi-nintendo27| title=Nintendo moves right along |first=Alex|last= Pham| newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date= October 27, 2008|accessdate=December 7, 2008}} In the United States the Wii had sold 10.9 million units by July 1, 2008, making it the leader in seventh generation home console sales according to the NPD Group (and surpassing the Xbox 360).{{cite web|url= http://www.gamespot.com/news/6194691.html|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081013021113/http://www.gamespot.com/news/6194691.html|archivedate= October 13, 2008 |title=NPD: PS3 sales spike on MGS4|first=Tom|last=Magrino|date=July 17, 2008|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|accessdate=November 22, 2008}}{{cite web|url= http://www.next-gen.biz/news/npd-wii-overtakes-360-us|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110815200337/http://www.next-gen.biz/news/npd-wii-overtakes-360-us|archivedate= August 15, 2011 | title=NPD: Wii Overtakes 360 in US|first=Joe|last=Keiser|publisher= ''[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]''|date=July 17, 2008|accessdate=November 22, 2008}}{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/techchron/detail?blogid=19&entry_id=28286 |title = E3: Nintendo Wii pulls ahead of Xbox 360 in console sales|first=Ryan|last=Kim| publisher=San Francisco Chronicle|date=July 17, 2008|accessdate=November 22, 2008}} In Japan the Wii surpassed the number of [[GameCube]] units sold by January 2008;{{cite web|url= http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=16914|title=Wii Sports Named Best Selling Game Of 2007 In Japan| last = Jenkins| first=David|date=January 11, 2008|publisher=[[Gamasutra]]|accessdate=February 2, 2008}} it sold 7,526,821 units by December 2008, according to Enterbrain.{{cite web|url= http://www.famitsu.com/game/news/1221045_1124.html |script-title=ja:2008年国内ゲーム市場規模は約5826億1000万円（エンターブレイン調べ）|work=[[Famitsu]]|publisher=[[Enterbrain]]|language=Japanese|date=January 5, 2009|accessdate=January 15, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5123288/last-year-japanese-game-market-experienced-shrinkage|title=Last Year, Japanese Game Market Experienced Shrinkage|first=Brian|last=Ashcraft|publisher=Kotaku|date= January 5, 2009|accessdate=January 15, 2009}} According to the NPD Group the Wii surpassed the Xbox 360 to become the best-selling "next-generation" home video-game console in Canada (with 813,000 units sold by April 1, 2008), and was the best-selling home console for 13 of the previous 17 months.{{cite press release|url= http://www.newswire.ca/en/releases/archive/April2008/17/c6749.html|title=Wii surpasses all other next generation consoles in lifetime sales|accessdate=April 24, 2008|date= April 17, 2008|publisher=[[Nintendo]]}}{{cite news|url= http://evergeek.thestar.com/news/2996.aspx|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080522144621/http://evergeek.thestar.com/news/2996.aspx|archivedate= May 22, 2008|title= NPD reports Nintendo Wii tops Canadian sales charts|date=April 22, 2008|work=Evergeek Media|publisher=[[Toronto Star]]|accessdate= August 2, 2008}} According to the NPD Group the Wii had sold a total of 1,060,000 units in Canada by August 2008, making it the first seventh generation home console to surpass the million-unit mark in that country. In the United Kingdom the Wii lead in seventh generation home-console sales with 4.9 million units sold {{as of|2009|01|03|lc=y|df=US}}, according to GfK [[Chart-Track]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/console-installed-base-reaches-22m-in-uk|title= Console installed base reaches 22m in UK|first=Matt|last=Martin|work=[[Eurogamer|GamesIndustry.biz]]|publisher=[[Eurogamer]]|date=January 13, 2009| accessdate=January 15, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mcvuk.com/news/31902/Nintendo-rules-official-UK-hardware-figures | title= Nintendo rules official UK hardware figures|first=Tim|last=Ingham|date=September 30, 2008|publisher=[[Market for Home Computing and Video Games]]|accessdate= October 2, 2008}} On March 25, 2009 at the [[Game Developers Conference]], [[Satoru Iwata]] said that worldwide shipments of Wii had reached 50 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/6206693.html?tag=recent_news;title;1 |title=Nintendo's GDC conference |date=March 25, 2009 |accessdate=March 25, 2009 |first=Tor |last=Thorsen |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326162924/http://www.gamespot.com/news/6206693.html?tag=recent_news%3Btitle%3B1 |archivedate=March 26, 2009 |df= }} According to [[GfK|GfK Australia]], the Wii had sold over 500,000 units in Australia within 84 weeks of its release, beating the [[PlayStation 2]] and the [[Nintendo DS|DS]] as the fastest system to accumulate 500,000 sales in that country.{{cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/500000-wiis-sold-in-australia/1100-6194895/ |title=500,000 Wiis sold in Australia |first=James |last=Kozanecki |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |date=July 23, 2008 |accessdate=October 31, 2008}} While Microsoft and Sony have experienced losses producing their consoles in the hopes of making a long-term profit on software sales, Nintendo reportedly has optimized production costs to obtain a significant profit margin with each Wii unit sold.{{cite web|url= http://seekingalpha.com/article/34357-game-console-wars-ii-nintendo-shaves-off-profits-leaving-competition-scruffy|date=May 3, 2007|author=Roger Ehrenberg|title=Game Console Wars II: Nintendo Shaves Off Profits, Leaving Competition Scruffy|publisher=seekingalpha.com| accessdate=June 10, 2007}} On September 17, 2007 the ''Financial Times'' reported that the direct profit per Wii sold may vary, from $13 in Japan to $49 in the United States and $79 in Europe.{{cite web|url= http://www.gamedaily.com/articles/features/report-nintendo-makes-about-49-per-wii-sold-in-us/70921/?biz=1|date=September 17, 2007|first=James|last=Brightman|title=Report: Nintendo Makes About $49 Per Wii Sold in U.S| publisher=gamingdaily.BIZ|accessdate=September 18, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100815075610/http://www.gamedaily.com/articles/features/report-nintendo-makes-about-49-per-wii-sold-in-us/70921/?biz=1|archivedate=August 15, 2010}} On December 2, 2008, ''[[Forbes]]'' reported that Nintendo made a $6 operating profit per Wii unit sold.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/6201833.html|title=Report: Nintendo banks $6 on each Wii sold|first=Tom|last=Magrino|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|date=December 2, 2008|accessdate=December 7, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100815075610/http://www.gamedaily.com/articles/features/report-nintendo-makes-about-49-per-wii-sold-in-us/70921/?biz=1|archivedate=August 15, 2010}} On September 23, 2009, Nintendo announced its first price reductions for the console.{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/corporate/release/2009/090924.html |title= ニュースリリース：2009年9月24日 | publisher =Nintendo.co.jp |accessdate=November 11, 2010}} Nintendo sold more than three million Wii consoles in the U.S. in December 2009 (setting a regional record for the month and ending nine months of declining sales), due to the price cut and software releases such as ''New Super Mario Bros. Wii''.{{cite web| author= Pavel Alpeyev| date= January 5, 2010| title= Nintendo Shares Rise After Record Wii Sales in U.S| publisher=[[Bloomberg Businessweek|BusinessWeek]]|url= http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-01-05/nintendo-shares-rise-after-record-wii-sales-in-u-s-update2-.html|accessdate =January 5, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100110004944/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-01-05/nintendo-shares-rise-after-record-wii-sales-in-u-s-update2-.html|archivedate=January 10, 2010}}{{cite news| author= Kiyoshi Takenaka| date= January 5, 2010| title= Nintendo Wii posts record U.S. sales in Dec| publisher=Reuters|url= https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTOE6040A420100105|accessdate =February 27, 2010}} On January 31, 2010 the Wii became the best-selling home video-game console produced by Nintendo, with sales of over 67 million units (surpassing those of the original [[Nintendo Entertainment System]]).{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100130202125/http://www.joystiq.com/2010/01/28/ds-sells-125-million-worldwide-wii-up-to-67-million/|title=DS sells 125 million worldwide, Wii up to 67 million|date=2010-01-30|access-date=2018-08-10}} In 2010, sales of the Wii began to decline, falling by 21 percent from the previous year.{{Cite news|url=https://kotaku.com/5532274/wii-sales-down-21-in-a-single-year?comment=22699923|title=Wii Sales Down 21% In A Single Year|last=Plunkett|first=Luke|work=Kotaku|access-date=2018-09-01|language=en-US}} The Wii continued to decline in 2011, with Nintendo's quarterly revenue dropping by 41 percent.{{Cite news|url=https://www.tomsguide.com/us/quarterly-earnings-q3-2011-wii-ds-3ds,news-13020.html|title=Nintendo Hit With Dramatic Decline in Sales|date=2011-10-27|work=Tom's Guide|access-date=2018-09-01|language=en}} Despite a slowdown in sales, Nintendo reported that on Black Friday in 2011, over 500,000 Wii consoles were sold, making it the most successful Black Friday in the Wii's history.{{cite news |title=Nintendo Wii has biggest-ever Black Friday, new Zelda game sets sales record |work=Boy Genius Report |date=December 1, 2011 |url=http://www.bgr.com/2011/12/01/nintendo-wii-has-biggest-ever-black-friday-new-zelda-game-sets-sales-record/ }} Wii sales declined even further in 2012, having decreased by half from 2011.{{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2012/07/25/nintendo-q1-results-wii-sales-cut-in-half-since-2011-but-3ds-s/|title=Nintendo Q1 results: Wii sales cut in half since 2011, but 3DS sales more than double|work=Engadget|access-date=2018-09-01|language=en-US}} The Wii Mini sold 35,700 units in its first two months of availability in Canada after being released on December 7, 2012.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130304072748/http://www.joystiq.com/2013/03/01/wii-mini-sells-35-700-units-in-canada-across-first-two-months/|title=Wii Mini sells 35,700 units in Canada across first two months {{!}} Joystiq|date=2013-03-04|access-date=2018-07-26}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nintendo.com/whatsnew/detail/ONIEEqvK1pbPyTbW2lWO6QnPUiqqvuuI|title=NINTENDO INTRODUCES NEW Wii MINI THAT'S ALL ABOUT THE GAMES - Nintendo Official Site|work=Nintendo.com|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en-us}} The Wii surpassed 100 million units sold on June 30, 2013, selling 210,000 units between March and June 2013.{{Cite news|url=https://www.gamezone.com/news/wii-lifetime-sales-surpass-100-million-units/|title=Wii lifetime sales surpass 100 million units - GameZone|date=2013-07-31|work=GameZone|access-date=2018-08-07|language=en-US}} ==Other models== ===Family Edition=== [[File:The_Remains_of_the_Nintendo_GameCube_Controller_Ports_and_Memory_Card_Slots_in_the_Wii_Family_Edition.jpg|thumb|right|Nintendo GameCube Controller Ports and Memory Card Slots' remains as it appears in the Wii Family Edition by removing the top cover.]][[File:The_Remains_of_the_Nintendo_GameCube_Controller_Ports_and_Memory_Card_Slots_in_the_Wii_Family_Edition_2.jpg|thumb|right|The Nintendo GameCube Controller Ports and Memory Card Slots' remains can be found in the Wii Family Edition's motherboard]] The '''Wii Family Edition''' is identical to the original model, but is designed to sit horizontally (the vertical feet are still present; however, the front labels are rotated and a stand is no longer included) and removes the [[GameCube]] controller and memory card ports, although the casing under the top cover still has the [[GameCube]] controller and memory card ports holes with no ports and no slots. For this reason, the Family Edition variant is incompatible with GameCube games and accessories. The console was announced on August 17, 2011 and was released in the United States on October 23, 2011 and Europe on November 4, 2011.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.uk/News/2011/Nintendo-launches-Wii-Family-Edition-on-4th-November-and-Wii-Fit-Plus-bundle-on-2nd-December-252719.html|title=Nintendo launches Wii Family Edition on 4th November and Wii Fit Plus bundle on 2nd December|website=Nintendo of Europe GmbH|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-08-31}}{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111114130448/http://www.officialnintendomagazine.co.uk/31328/newsnew-black-wii-bundle-includes-mario-cd/|title=Wii News: New black Wii bundle includes Mario CD - Official Nintendo Magazine|date=2011-11-14|access-date=2018-08-31}} The Wii Family Edition was made available in Europe, bundled with a [[Wii Remote Plus]], ''[[Wii Party]]'' and ''[[Wii Sports]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/new-slim-wii-announced-won-t-play-gamecube-games-209100.phtml|publisher=Destructoid|work=Destructoid|title=New slim Wii announced, won't play GameCube games|accessdate=August 17, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/nintendo-no-plans-for-slim-wii-in-north-america-209130.phtml|publisher=Destructoid|work=Destructoid|title=Nintendo: No plans for slim Wii in North America|accessdate=August 17, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.officialnintendomagazine.co.uk/29791/new-wii-is-same-size-as-old-wii/ |title=New Wii is same size as old Wii |publisher=Official Nintendo Magazine |date=August 23, 2011 |accessdate=August 23, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928121842/http://www.officialnintendomagazine.co.uk/29791/new-wii-is-same-size-as-old-wii/ |archivedate=September 28, 2011 }}{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.uk/NOE/en_GB/news/2011/nintendo_announces_packed_2011_line-up_of_upcoming_games_44323.html|title=Nintendo announces packed 2011 line-up of upcoming games|date=August 17, 2011|publisher=Nintendo|accessdate=August 17, 2011}} A blue Wii Family Edition was launched to coincide with [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]] and the release of ''[[Mario & Sonic at the London 2012 Olympic Games]]'' on November 18, 2011{{cite web|url=http://mynintendonews.com/2011/10/10/nintendo-wii-nintendo-is-releasing-a-blue-wii-console-in-november/ |title=Nintendo Wii: Nintendo Is Releasing A Blue Wii Console In November |publisher=My Nintendo News |accessdate=October 10, 2011}} and a black Wii Family Edition (bundled with ''New Super Mario Bros. Wii'' and the official soundtrack CD of ''[[Super Mario Galaxy]]'') was released on October 23, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://mynintendonews.com/2011/10/11/nintendo-wii-black-wii-holiday-bundle-with-new-super-mario-bros-wii-and-exclusive-mario-music-cd/ |title=Nintendo Wii: Black Wii Holiday Bundle With New Super Mario Bros Wii And Exclusive Mario Music CD |date=October 11, 2011}} In late 2012, Nintendo released a version of the North America black edition, including ''[[Wii Sports]]'' and ''[[Wii Sports Resort]]'' games on a single disc instead of the ''New Super Mario Bros. Wii'' game and the ''Super Mario Galaxy'' soundtrack.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/nintendo-wii-now-bundled-wii-sports-price-slashed-015348111.html |title=Nintendo Wii now bundled with Wii Sports, price slashed to just $129 |date=October 15, 2011}} ===Wii Mini=== [[File:Wii-Mini-Console-Set-H.jpg|thumb|right|A Wii Mini with Wii Remote]] The '''Wii Mini''' (stylized as '''Wii mini''') is a smaller, redesigned Wii with a top-loading disc drive. It was announced on November 27, 2012 and released on December 7, 2012 in Canada with a MSRP of [[Canadian dollar|C$]]99.99. The system was later released in Europe on March 22, 2013,{{Cite web|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20150907235732/http://www.digitalspy.com.au/gaming/news/a461694/wii-mini-confirmed-for-europe-launching-next-month.html|title=Wii Mini confirmed for Europe, launching next month - Gaming News - Digital Spy|date=2015-09-07|access-date=2018-08-31}} and in the United States on November 17, 2013.{{Cite web|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20131107012351/https://www.nintendo.com/wiimini/buynow/|title=Wii mini Official Site - Buy Now|date=2013-11-07|access-date=2018-08-31}} It was not released in Japan, Australia or New Zealand. This console lacks [[YPbPr|{{YPbPr}}]] ([[component video]]/[[D-Terminal]]), [[S-Video]], [[RGBS|RGB]] [[SCART]] output, [[GameCube]] compatibility, online connectivity, the [[SD card]] slot and [[Wi-Fi]] support, and has only one [[USB]] port unlike the previous models' two.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/df-hardware-nintendo-wii-mini-review|title= Nintendo Wii Mini review |last=Leadbetter|first=Richard|date=December 12, 2012|work=Eurogamer|accessdate=December 16, 2012}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.com/consumer/downloads/WiiMiniOpMn_RVO_en.pdf|title= Nintendo Wii Mini Operations Manual|publisher=Nintendo of America|page=10|accessdate=December 16, 2012|quote=The Wii Mini console will not work with any AV cable other than the model supplied.}} The initial release omitted a [[pack-in game]], but ''[[Mario Kart Wii]]'' was included at no extra charge beginning on September 18, 2013 in Canada,{{cite web|title=Mario Kart Wii picture |publisher=Future Shop |url=http://www.futureshop.ca/multimedia/Products/500x500/102/10270/10270488.jpg |date=September 18, 2013 |accessdate=September 18, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131003015233/http://www.futureshop.ca/multimedia/Products/500x500/102/10270/10270488.jpg |archivedate=October 3, 2013 }} and from launch in the United States.{{Cite news|url=https://www.tomsguide.com/us/nintendo-wii-mini-pros-cons,news-17823.html|title=Should You Buy a Wii Mini? -- Tom's Guide|date=2013-11-05|work=Tom's Guide|access-date=2018-08-31|language=en}} Nintendo uses this console and the [[Nintendo Selects]] game series to promote low-cost gaming. The Wii Mini is styled in matte black with a red border, and includes a red [[Wii Remote Plus]] and Nunchuk. A [[composite video]]/audio cable, wired sensor bar and power adapter are also included.{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2012/12/06/nintendo-wii-mini-hands-on/|title=Nintendo Wii Mini hands-on |last=Fingas|first=Jon|date=December 6, 2012|work=Engadget|publisher=AOL|accessdate=December 12, 2012}} ==Successor== {{Main article|Wii U}} Nintendo announced the successor to the Wii, [[Wii U]], at the [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2011]].{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/video-games/nintendo/8563836/Nintendos-Wii-U-unveiled-at-E3-keeping-Nintendos-revolution-going.html|title=Nintendo's Wii U unveiled at E3: keeping Nintendo's revolution going|date=June 8, 2012|accessdate=September 13, 2012|publisher=Telegraph|first=Tom|last=Hoggins}} The Wii U features a controller with an embedded touch screen and output [[1080p]] [[high-definition video|high-definition]] graphics; it is fully backward-compatible with Wii games and peripherals for the Wii. The Wii remote, Nunchuk controller and balance board are compatible with Wii U games which include support for them.{{cite web|url=http://www.extremetech.com/gaming/136121-nintendo-confirms-wii-u-specs-and-release-date-prices-it-above-xbox-360-and-ps3|title=Nintendo confirms Wii U specs and release date, prices it above Xbox 360 and PS3|date=September 13, 2012|accessdate=September 13, 2012|publisher=Extreme Tech|first=Sebastian|last=Anthony}} The Wii U was released on November 18, 2012 in North America, November 30, 2012 in Europe, Australia and New Zealand, December 8, 2012 in Japan{{Cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/09/13/wii-u-price-release-date-announced|title=Wii U Price, Release Date Announced|last=Goldfarb|first=Andrew|date=2012-09-13|website=IGN|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-22}} and November 26, 2013 in [[Brazil]].{{Cite news|url=http://nintendotoday.com/brazil-finally-getting-wii-u/|title=Brazil finally gets the Wii U, will cost R$1899 - NintendoToday|date=2013-11-08|work=NintendoToday|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en-US}} The Wii U was discontinued worldwide on January 31, 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://kotaku.com/wii-u-production-has-officially-ended-for-japan-1791813878|title=Wii U Production Has Officially Ended For Japan [Update]|last=Ashcraft|first=Brian|work=Kotaku|access-date=2018-06-19|language=en-US}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Commons category-inline|Wii}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060928040528/http://wii.com/ Global and general Wii site] {{Wii}} {{Nintendo hardware|Wii}} {{Seventh generation game consoles}} {{Home video game consoles}} {{Portal bar|Electronics|Nintendo|Video games}} [[Category:Wii| ]] [[Category:Backward-compatible video game consoles]] [[Category:Home video game consoles]] [[Category:Power Architecture]] [[Category:Seventh-generation video game consoles]] [[Category:Wii hardware| ]] [[Category:2000s in video gaming]] [[Category:2010s in video gaming]] [[Category:2000s toys]] [[Category:2010s toys]] [[Category:2006 in video gaming]] [[Category:Computer-related introductions in 2006]] [[Category:Products introduced in 2006]] [[Category:Discontinued products]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox NRHP | name =Wright Cycle Company & Wright and Wright Printing Offices and Shop | nrhp_type =nhl | image =Wright Cycle Company Offices.jpg | caption = Rented by Wright Brothers, 1895-97<ref>{{Cite web | last = Quinn Evans/Architects | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Historic Structure Report The Wright Cycle Company Building | work = | publisher = Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park, National Park Service, U.S. Department of the Interior | date = May 1999 | url = http://www.nps.gov/history/history/online_books/daav/wright_cycle.pdf | format = | doi = | accessdate = October 26, 2011}} </ref> | location= 22 South Williams St., [[Dayton, Ohio]] | coordinates = {{coord|39|45|13.14|N|84|12|43.17|W|display=inline,title}} | area = | built =1886 | architect= Abraham and Joseph Nicholas | architecture= Late Victorian | added = February 13, 1986 | designated_nrhp_type = June 21, 1990 | governing_body = National Park Service | refnum=86000236 <ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2006a}}</ref> }}
The [[bicycle]] business of the [[Wright brothers]], '''the Wright Cycle Company''' (originally the ''Wright Cycle Exchange'') successively occupied six different locations in [[Dayton, Ohio]]. Orville and Wilbur Wright began their bicycle repair, rental and sales business in 1892, while continuing to operate a print shop (they ended their local newspaper business in 1890).<ref name="WDL">{{cite web |url = http://www.wdl.org/en/item/11373/ |title = Wilbur Wright Working in the Bicycle Shop |website = [[World Digital Library]] |date = 1897 |accessdate = 2013-07-22 }}</ref> In 1896 they began manufacturing and selling bicycles of their own design, the ''Van Cleve'' and ''St. Claire'', named after their ancestors. They invented the self-oiling hub and the innovation of machining the [[crankarm]] and pedal on the left side of the bike with left-hand threads to prevent the pedal from coming unscrewed while cycling. The brick building at 22 South Williams St., where the Wrights worked from 1895 to 1897, is the only extant building on its original foundation and in its original location that housed a Wright bicycle shop. They ran their printing shop on the second-floor. The 22 South Williams Street building is part of [[Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park]] and the [[National Aviation Heritage Area]].<ref name=naha1>{{cite web|title=Home of the Wright Brothers|url=http://www.aviationheritagearea.org/|publisher=National Aviation Heritage Area|accessdate=16 March 2012}}</ref>
The Wrights used the profits from the Wright Cycle Company to finance their aviation experiments.<ref name="WDL"/> In 1901 they fitted a third bicycle wheel horizontally above the front wheel of one of their St. Claire bicycles and used the apparatus as a test platform to study [[airfoil]] design. They built a six-foot [[wind tunnel]] on the second floor of their bicycle shop at 1127 West Third St., the last location of their bicycle business, and from October to December they conducted pioneering tests in the tunnel of over 200 shapes of scale-model wings.<ref name="WDL"/>
In that same building they designed and constructed their gliders and first airplane, the [[Wright Flyer]], which cost under $1,000 to build.<ref name="WDL"/> The shop closed in 1909 and they started their aviation company.<ref name="WDL"/> In 1937, with Orville's cooperation, the building at 1127 West Third St. was moved to [[Greenfield Village, Michigan#Greenfield Village|Greenfield Village]], Dearborn, Michigan by [[Henry Ford]]. [[Image:Wright Cycle Dayton AirForce Museum 2007.jpg|thumb|Wright bicycle in [[National Museum of the United States Air Force]], Dayton, Ohio]]
==Shop Locations==
With the exception of the West Second Street location, which is located near the [[Schuster Center]] on the other side of the Miami River, all of the shops are located within about one block of each other.I
*1892—Wright Cycle Exchange at 1005 West Third Street<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/daav/learn/historyculture/wrightcycleexchange.htm|title=Wright Cycle Exchange - Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park (U.S. National Park Service)|website=www.nps.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-05-29}}</ref> *1893—Wright Cycle Exchange at 1015 West Third Street<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.wright-brothers.org/Information_Desk/Just_the_Facts/Bicycles/Wright_Bicycles.htm|title=Wright Bicycles|website=www.wright-brothers.org|access-date=2018-05-29}}</ref> *1893 to 1894—Wright Cycle Exchange at 1034 West Third Street. The name later changed to Wright Cycle Co. *1895 to 1897—Wright Cycle Co. at two locations—the main store at 22 South Williams Street, and a branch store in downtown Dayton at 23 West Second Street.The branch closed in 1896. *1897 to 1909—The Wright Cycle Co. at 1127 West Third Street.<ref name=":0" />
== Wright Cycle Exchange (1892-1893) == After both brothers purchased bicycles in the spring of 1892, their aptitude with bicycle repairs and the high demand for repairmen led them to starting their own repair shop. In December of 1892 they rented a storefront at 1005 West Third Street, where they officially started the Wright Cycle Exchange. They sold bicycles from $40 to $100. In addition to these sales, they rented bicycles, and sold parts and accessories.<ref name=":0" /> The brothers then moved the shop to 1015 West Third street, where they even had a newspaper ad for the Exchange.<ref name=":0" /> By the end of 1893 the shop was moved to 1034 West Third Street, where the name was changed from Wright Cycle Exchange to Wright Cycle Company.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cliffhanger76.tripod.com/bikewest/wright/index.html|title=The Bicycle & The West - The Wright Cycle Company|website=cliffhanger76.tripod.com|access-date=2018-05-29}}</ref>
== Wright Cycle Company (1894-1909) == In 1895 the Wright Brothers moved to 22 South Williams Street,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/daav/learn/historyculture/wright-cycle-company-complex.htm|title=Wright Cycle Company Complex - Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park (U.S. National Park Service)|website=www.nps.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-05-29}}</ref> the only location of the six that is still standing today. It has been turned into the Wright Cycle Company Complex and the [[National Aviation Heritage Area]]. A second branch opened at 20 West Second Street in 1895, but closed down the next year. In 1986 the Wright Brothers began selling their own bikes. They sold the more expensive ''Van Cleve'', and the cheaper ''St. Clair.''<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.wright-brothers.org/History_Wing/Wright_Story/Career_Choices/Bicycle_Craze/Bicycle_Craze.htm|title=The Bicycle Craze|website=www.wright-brothers.org|access-date=2018-05-29}}</ref> Orville made his own additions to the bicycles, including the Oil-Retaining Wheel Hub.<ref name=":1" /> This was the greatest era of success for the Wright Brothers.They operated at 22 South Williams Street from 1895 to 1897.
In 1897 the Wright Brothers moved their shop to 1127 West Third Street, the sixth and final location for the Wright Cycle Company. In 1900 they produced their [http://www.wright-brothers.org/Information_Desk/Just_the_Facts/Bicycles/Van_Cleve_Catalog.htm Van Cleve Catalog], a catalog which promoted their famous ''Van Cleve'', which now came in two models.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wright-brothers.org/Information_Desk/Just_the_Facts/Bicycles/Van_Cleve_Catalog.htm|title=1900 Van Cleve Catalogue|website=www.wright-brothers.org|access-date=2018-05-29}}</ref> After becoming increasingly invested in [[Wright Glider|the Wright Glider]], the Brothers manufactured very few bicycles after 1902, and completely stopped after 1904. In 1909, the shop at 1127 West Third Street was converted completely for airplanes, and the Wright Brothers sold the company to W.F. Meyers, who continued to sell ''Van Cleves'' until 1939.<ref name=":0" /> This marks the end of the Wright Cycle Company.{{double image|left|OrvilleInBikeShop.jpg|225|WilburInBikeShop.jpg|225|Left photo: Orville and boyhood friend Ed Sines (left); right photo: Wilbur. Both photographs show the 1127 West Third Street bicycle shop in 1897.}} {{clear}}
